_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Hazard Assessment was conducted to fulfill the requirements for the Risk Management Plan (RMP) for Gilbert Orchards, Inc, a Washington Corporation, located in Yakima County in accordance with 40 CFR Part 68, Section 1129(r) under the Clean Air Act.  The hazardous material used in the refrigeration system is anhydrous ammonia.  The threshold quantity for this regulated substance is 10,000 lbs.  Gilbert Orchards has approximately 14,317 lbs of ammonia in their system.  The largest vessel could potentially release 9,647 lbs.

  

Gilbert Orchards' prevention program is based on the following:

   * Initial and continued training of personnel

   * Preventative maintenance program as described in the PSM program

   * Use of safety equipment and procedures

   * Use of accurate and effective written operating procedures



Gilbert Orchards complies with:

   * OSHA's and Washington State's process safety management rules

   * Washington State's safety regulations

   * IIAR (International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration) standards for good work practices.



The ammonia refrigeration system was installed to standards and local codes at the time of installation.  Piping and equipment is secured and protected; engine room doors are generally closed, tight fitting and open outwards; computerized controls allow remote operating of system; suction trap hi-level float; high discharge pressure shut down; low suction pressure shut down; high discharge temperature shut down; oil pressure failure shut down; high amperes shut down; automatic timer to prevent short cycling via computer controls; oil filters plugged shut down; 250 psi relief valves on high pressure side, to prevent overpressure situations; and 150 psi relief valves on low pressure side, to prevent overpressure situation.



Gilbert Orchards has had no accidents or ammonia releases in the past 5 years that have caused significant on-site or off-site damage.



The Yakima County Fire Department has received a

copy of the Emergency Response Plan and have walked through the plant so they are familiarized with the facility, the evacuation plan and contact information for Gilbert Orchards.  The Fire Department will call Yakima County's Hazmat Team in the case of a large release.  Gilbert Orchards' employees have not been trained to respond in a Hazmat situation, and do not have the necessary equipment. 



Gilbert Orchards has developed a Hot Work Permit program, Lock-out / Tag-out system and a Confined Space Entry Program.  Employees have been trained on these programs, and will be retrained and refreshed on the procedures as needed and as required by regulations.
